Award.AwardTitle: PFI:AIR - TT: Real-Time Fatigue Life Prediction for Decision-making and Asset Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
This PFI: AIR Technology Translation project from Tufts University focuses on a Fatigue Health Portal (FHP), for translation of an advanced technology for real-time fatigue life prediction of in-service bridge structures. This product would fill an existing need to monitor and assess the conditions of aging US infrastructures. No existing product on the market offers real-time continuous operational fatigue prognosis and remaining life predictions, thus creating a market niche for the FHP. Full development, licensing, and commercialization of the FHP is vital as the US infrastructure ages, deteriorates and is thus increasingly "load-posted" (not recommended for transportation of materials and goods using heavier trucks). Load posting of bridges has major societal and commercial impact on the US market and economy and results in enormous costs of maintenance, retrofit, and replacement of the US highway bridges. An intelligent decision-oriented methodology can exploit real-time measured data and analysis, resulting in a more effective use of such information for infrastructure health monitoring and management. It will support a paradigm shift in the fatigue assessment profession to enable a data-driven and decision-oriented tool that can evolve as more structural response data is collected.

The target market for this methodology is bridge managers and owners concerned with limited service life due to fatigue of steel elements. The broader target market is any structural engineer interested in data-driven intelligent decision-making with respect to fatigue assessment of in-service structures, such as transmission towers or amusement park rides. Under this project, two full-scale bridges and one other structural type will be the case studies for validation of the proposed methodologies, allowing refinement of the analytical methods and experimental techniques to address challenges of commercialization. The project will result in a FHP prototype software package with proof-of-concept that meets the need for improved decision-making in infrastructure asset management. It will integrate structural health monitoring concepts, analytical fatigue life prediction, and advanced nonparametric statistical methods to enable real-time fatigue assessment and prognosis to be used for decision-making and asset management. This project addresses the following technology gaps for real-time decision-making: (1) efficient and reliable wireless sensors, data acquisition, cloud computing, and data communications, (2) nonparametric decision-oriented probabilistic operational methods for infrastructure fatigue assessments, and (3) prognosis and prediction of remaining infrastructure fatigue life.

The FHP has the following unique features: variable fatigue stress ranges, operational measured strains, unknown vehicle information, hypothesis testing for damage assessment, and use of an alert system that improves system safety. These features provide the following advantages: real-time structural fatigue life assessment using real-time measured strains, and use of efficient computational methodologies, which are cost effective when compared to the leading competing products and technology in this market space. This research collaboration, which involves three departments (Civil Engineering, Computer Science, and Economics) at two universities (Tufts University and University of New Hampshire), will strive to include underrepresented groups at the graduate, undergraduate, and high school level (students and teachers). In addition, personnel involved in this project will receive innovation, entrepreneurship, and technology translation experiences through product development, proof of concept, capstone projects, and licensing process of the IP. The academic and industrial partners of this project are looking forward to working together to transform research discoveries into market-ready products.

The lead institution is Tufts University with its departments of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Computer Science, and Economics. The primary subcontractor is the University of New Hampshire, with a current PFI BIC project, The Living Bridge: The Future of Smart, User-Centered Transportation Infrastructure, which will be used for proof of concept of the FHP. Primary industrial partner is Bridge Diagnostic Inc. (BDI) to transform research discoveries into market-ready products and contact with consumers of FHP. Broader context partners are Six Flags New England, New Hampshire Department of Transportation, and Massachusetts Department of Transportation.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Our vision is introducing an intelligent decision-oriented methodology that can exploit real-time data leading to more effective use of such data in infrastructure health monitoring, management, and decision-making. Our goal is to further develop and deliver an intelligent real-time decision support system for fatigue life prediction. We used our previous NSF PFI supported experience at the Powder Mill Bridge (PMB) in MA, validated it at Six Flags New England (SFNE), and implemented it at The Memorial Bridge (TMB) in NH. Existing research discovery from this project includes: (1) specifications and requirements for instrumentation and data acquisition (DAQ) using operational strain measurements for real-time monitoring of full-scale bridges excited by daily traffic, (2) establishing non-model based structural condition assessment models using statistical decision theory, and (3) fatigue prognosis and remaining fatigue life predictions.

The Intellectual Merit of the proposed project is addressing the operational challenges that prevent data-driven decision-making in the fatigue assessment of in-service structures. There are knowledge and implementation gaps associated with the creation of a prototype Fatigue Health Portal (FHP) for real-time fatigue assessment relating to (1) fast and reliable wireless sensors, data acquisition, cloud computing, and data communications, (2) nonparametric probabilistic operational methods for infrastructure fatigue studies, and (3) prognosis and prediction of remaining fatigue life. This project integrated structural health monitoring concepts, analytical fatigue life prediction, and advanced nonparametric statistical methods to enable real-time fatigue assessment and prognosis.

Broader Impacts: The methodology developed by this research grant supports a paradigm shift in the fatigue assessment profession to a data-driven decision-making tool that can improve as more structural response data is collected from a visual inspection paired with costly destructive evaluation techniques. Other countries are facing similar challenges maintaining their built environment, and therefore this prototype is of great value worldwide.

This research grant was conducted over five departments (Tufts CEE, CS, and Econ; UNH CEE and CS) at two universities educated underrepresented groups in the research at the graduate and undergraduate students and faculty. We supported two Ph.D. students at Tufts and UNH in support of this PFI grant. We also supported five undergraduate REU students.

The following 5 peer-reviewed journal articles are produced fully or partially by this PFI grant. In addition, 4 conference papers are published and presented. G=Graduate U=Undergraduate

Peer-Reviewed Journal Articles:

[1]       Sofia Puerto TchemodanovaG, Masoud Sanayei, Babak Moaveni, Konstantinos Tatsis, and Eleni Chatzi (2021) Strain predictions at unmeasured locations of a rollercoaster section using sparse response-only measurements, Journal Civil Structural Health Monitoring, Volume 147 Issue 5.

[2]       Sofia Puerto TchemodanovaG, Maryam MashayekhiG, Masoud Sanayei, Erin Santini Bell (2021) Multiaxial fatigue assessment of complex steel connections: A case study of a vertical-lift gussetless truss bridge, Engineering Structures, Vol. 235.

[3]       Sofia Puerto TchemodanovaG, Masoud Sanayei, Konstantinos Tatsis, Vasilis Dertimanis, and Eleni Chatzi (2021) State estimation for prediction of fatigue life for a rollercoaster connection subjected to operational multiaxial nonproportional loading, Journal of Structural Engineering. Volume 147 Issue 5.

[4]       Kathryn KasparG, Erin Santini-Bell, Marek Petrik, Masoud Sanayei, (2020) Comparison Between a Linear Regression and an Artificial Neural Network Model to Detect and Localize Damage in the Powder Mill Bridge, Transportation Research Record: Journal of the Transportation Research Board, Volume: 2674, Issue 8.

[5]       Justin G. Chen, Travis M. AdamsG, Hao Sun, Erin S. Bell, Oral Buyukozturk, (2018) Camera-Based Vibration Measurement of the World War I Memorial Bridge in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, Journal of Structural Engineering, Vol. 144, Issue 11 (November 2018).

Conference Papers Publications with Presentations:

[6]       Sofia Puerto TchemodanovaG and Masoud Sanayei (2020) What rollercoasters can teach us about fatigue life of bridge connections, Society for Experimental Mechanics, IMAC-XXXVIII Conference & Exhibition on Structural Dynamics, Houston, TX. Conference Proceedings of the Society for Experimental Mechanics Series book series (CPSEMS) Dynamics of Civil Structures, Volume 2, September 23, 2020 DOI: 0.1007/978-3-030-47634-2_2, Presented by Sanayei.

[7]       Sofia Puerto TchemodanovaG, Masoud Sanayei, and Erin Santini Bell (2019) Multiaxial fatigue life assessment of a vertical-lift bridge connection using strain rosette data, The International Bridge Conference 2019, Washington DC. DOI: eswp.com/product/ibc-19-40/. Presented by Puerto.

[8]       Sofia Puerto TchemodanovaG, Konstantinos Tatsis, Vasilis Dertimanis, Eleni Chatzi, and Masoud Sanayei (2019) Remaining Fatigue Life Prediction of a Roller Coaster Subjected to Multiaxial Nonproportional Loading Using Limited Measured Strain Locations, Structures Congress Conference 2019, Orlando, Florida. Presented by Puerto.

[9]       Owen SearlsU, Zhiyong ZhaoG, Alva L. Couch, and Masoud Sanayei (2019), Real-time Distributed Cloud Computing Architecture for Structural Health Monitoring, ASCE/SEI Structures Congress Conference 2019, Orlando, Florida. Presented by Sanayei.
